p.span: ) Per the Order of Governor Baker, the Masconomet Regional School District will be
closed for the remainder of the 2019-2020 school year

The information detailed in this document is intended to provide guidance for this period. It is important to note that this is a fluid situation and information may change. This document will be regularly updated and modified as information becomes available. You should revisit frequently for the latest updates and information.
Click on the link below for the questions specific to:
How will the days of the closure count against school days?
) The Masconomet School Committee has voted to set the last day of school for students as Tuesday, June 16, 2020.

The Commissioner of Education has waived the requirement that school districts in Massachusetts make up days missed to cancellation past their originally scheduled 185th day (180 school days + 5 snow days). The last possible day of school for the Masconomet Regional District will be Monday, June 22nd.
) Currently the schools are closed through
. Will this be extended? How will we be notified?

The Masconomet Regional School District will continue to monitor this fluid situation and will make the best determinations in the best interest of the students and staff. Information will continue to be provided via Blackboard Connect, on our website, via Twitter (
) and on all major news outlets.
What will happen to April vacation (April 20-24)?

) The School Committee has voted to continue the Masconomet Remote Learning Plan over April Vacation Week. Remote Learning Classes will be held from April 21-24. Monday, April 20 will still be observed as a state holiday (Patriots’ Day).

he April vacation week is currently scheduled as planned. However, given the extended school closure through April 6, it may be necessary to recapture some instructional time through holding school during the vacation week. We will make every effort to communicate a decision regarding whether we will hold classes in April as soon as possible.
Will there be access to any school buildings during the 2020 closure?
No. The entire campus is closed. All buildings and facilities will be closed until at least
How can I pick up medication that my child has at school?
Karen Trevenen, Interim Health Services Director, will be available during certain times during the week of March 16th for parents to come and pick up any needed medication. Please email
Will food services be available for students who qualify for free and reduced lunch?

): “Grab and Go” lunches will be available for ALL STUDENTS to pick up at Door #27 of the High School outside of the Small Cafeteria daily from 11:00 AM -1:00 PM beginning on March 18th. Lunches will include assorted sandwiches along with a piece of fruit, a snack and drink. A gluten free option will be available on an as needed basis. The cafeteria will not be open to sit down and eat.
What is the Masconomet Remote Learning Plan?

is the next phase in our process to continue supporting students’ social-emotional and educational development. In this plan, students will follow a regular schedule to work in their current-year courses. Teachers will be posting instructional activities and assignments to their pages in the District’s Remote Learning Platform,
What was the Commissioner’s Guidance around Remote Learning?
The Masconomet Remote Learning Plan was developed in accordance with

span.a: guidance provided by Commissioner of Education Jeff Riley on March 26, 2019

p.span: . The highlights of this guidance include:

li.span: Schools and districts need to ensure that students, staff and their families are safe and that schools are not only focused on the academic needs, but also the social-emotional needs of students,
Equity in terms of safeguarding our most vulnerable student populations needs to be a primary consideration in plan development,
Remote learning cannot replicate the in-person school experience,
Schools have an obligation to engage students in meaningful and productive structured learning experiences,
Remote learning can take place in a multitude of ways, including student engagement with resources in their everyday lives, and the natural world.
Students should be graded on a “credit/no credit” basis for work completed during remote learning.

p.span: What are the expectations for students in the Remote Learning Plan?

Students should log into their Blackboard Learn Accounts at the times listed in the schedule for the appropriate course listed on their current 2019-2020 class schedule and complete the learning activities that have been prepared by their teacher.
How can students ask questions for their teachers?

Teachers will be available to answer students’ questions during the class period. Teachers will communicate to students how they would like to receive questions from students (email, discussion board, video conference, etc.). Additionally, teachers will be available to answer student questions during the periods listed on Friday as “Office Hours.”
Will the curriculum for the remote learning plan be “enrichment” or will it be new material?

While teachers may decide that providing a review of prior material may be appropriate, they can also decide to move the curriculum forward through presenting new material. These decisions will be made by teachers working in conjunction with their colleagues who teach the same courses and their Department Heads. The goal of this work is to ensure consistency between different sections of the same course.
Why are there two 1.5 hour “classes” each day?

The Remote Learning Plan schedule follows the guidance from the Commissioner of Education, who recommended that students be engaged in “meaningful and productive learning for approximately half the length of a regular school day.”
How will students be assessed during the Remote Learning Plan?

In accordance with the recommendations of Commissioner Riley, all student work will be graded on a “Credit/No Credit” basis for the duration of the Remote Learning Plan. We believe that specific, targeted feedback from teachers regarding student work is an integral part of the learning process that should continue during the Remote Learning Plans. However, assigning traditional letter “grades” to work completed when both teachers are students are unfamiliar with the learning environment would not be an accurate reflection of the student’s mastery of the content.
What if I need a device to access the Remote Learning Plan?
As the District has a limited supply of devices on hand, we will be communicating directly with targeted groups to assess the need for devices and make arrangements to distribute them.

, we will make District-owned Chromebooks available to all Middle School students who are in need of a device. These Chromebooks will be available at Door #27 of the High School (off the small café of the HS) from 9:00 AM – 1:00 PM. There is no requirement to notify us in advance; just arrive during the timeframe/location specified and you will be assigned a District-owned Chromebook.
What if I need Internet access during the Remote Learning Plan?

) Please see the information below from Comcast regarding its special programming for internet access during the COVID-19 Pandemic. This information should in no way be construed as a District endorsement of Comcast:
On March 16, Comcast introduced two substantial enhancements to Internet Essentials, the nation's largest and most comprehensive broadband adoption program for low-income Americans.

li.span: Comcast is making it easier for low-income families who live in a Comcast service area to sign up by offering new customers 60 days of complimentary Internet Essentials service, which is normally available to all qualified low-income households for .95/month.

Comcast increased Internet speeds for the Internet Essentials service from 15/2 Mbps to 25/3 Mbps for all new and existing customers, which will be the speed of the service going forward. In this way, we will ensure that Internet Essentials customers will be able to use their Internet service for all their increased needs as a result of this health crisis.

p.span: To sign up, applicants can simply visit

. The accessible website also includes the option to video chat with customer service agents in American Sign Language. There are also two dedicated phone numbers 1-855-846-8376 for English and 1-855-765-6995 for Spanish.

li.span: New customers can apply by visiting
. The accessible website also includes the option to video chat with customer service agents in American Sign Language. For additional assistance, chat with us anytime through the
Existing customers do not need to do anything to access the speed increase – you’ve already received it!

p.span: What if my child has a technology problem during the Remote Learning Plan?
) The Information Technology Department has created
to assist students who may be having technical difficulties accessing the Remote Learning Plan.

) Students who experience technology issues during the Remote Learning Plan should notify one of their teachers about the issue. Teachers will then fill out a “help ticket” with our IT Department so IT can address the issue.
Are the days during the closure counted as “school days?”

)The Massachusetts Commissioner of Education has directed schools to institute a “remote learning model” to begin on April 6. More information will be forthcoming about this plan during the week of March 30.

No. These are non-school days. These days will essentially be considered a three week school closing period (March 16 -April 6). There is no expectation of online learning or for the provision of educational services during this period. It is important to note that the school year will not extend beyond the District's originally scheduled 185th day, which is June 22, 2020.
Are there expectations around Distance and Online Learning Expectations for Students or Teachers?
) Beginning on April 6, school districts will be instituting a “remote learning model.” More information on Masconomet’s Model will be released during the week of March 30.

The Massachusetts Department of Elementary and Secondary Education has informed us that we may not use distance or online learning experiences to replace in-person teaching at this time. This is to ensure equitable educational access to students across the Commonwealth and to

span.a: ensure students with learning needs are not denied their mandated accommodations

p.span: . The days we are closed are “non-school days” and so there is only an expectation of “continuation of learning.” These experiences are not mandatory and are not considered instruction.
Students should not be completing assignments that are due to be graded and teachers should not be assigning new work or expecting students to submit work to be graded.
What resources are available to enrich learning during this period of closure?

): Beginning on Friday, March 27th, teachers will be available to answer their students’ questions regarding the enrichment activities. Each Educator will post individual hours of availability on Blackboard. Students should check their Blackboard Accounts on Thursday to find out when teachers will be available to contact. Please understand that the hours teachers will be available will vary due to the unique situation of each educator.
for students to work on during the hiatus. We recommend that parents/guardians set up a regular schedule with their children where they will choose an activity to work on for a few hours each day.
The Department of Elementary and Secondary Education and WGBH TV have also created a website of resources for Massachusetts students to use during the shutdown. These resources are located at:
Given the extended closure, what happens with the MCAS test?

) On March 24, Governor Baker filed a bill with the Massachusetts Legislature to grant the Commissioner of Education the authority to waive the requirements that all graduating senior pass the MCAS Test, and the requirement that all students in Grades 3-8 and 10 are tested annually. Once this bill passes the Legislature, the Commissioner will make a decision regarding the MCAS.
We will not be in school during the previously scheduled MCAS ELA window. The Department of Elementary and Secondary Education is contemplating whether to re-schedule the MCAS for this year.
) The College Board has announced the cancellation of the May 2 SAT administration. Please see:
What is the plan for Advanced Placement (AP) Testing?
) The College Board announced contingency plans for schools on March 20th. Please see:
for more information on AP Testing and Resources
My child is on an IEP or 504 Plan, and I am concerned about the implications of the closure on my child’s educational progress.

Upon the conclusion of the closure, and the re-opening of the district, IEP teams will be available to convene to determine what type of impact the closure had on your child’s educational progress, and make individualized team based decisions as needed.The United States Department of Education advisory indicates that if the District “does not provide any educational services to the general student population, then an LEA would not be required to provide services to students with disabilities during that same period of time.” Please see the full advisory in the link below.

span.a: Please refer to the following guidance from the US DOE.

p.span: My child is on an IEP and attends an out of district placement. What are the implications of Masconomet’s closure on my child attending the out of district placement.

Masconomet’s closure should not have any impact on your child attending the out of district placement. As information is changing daily, please communicate directly with the outplacement school for any updates on their closures.
My child is on an IEP and receives “services only” (i.e. speech/Language counseling etc.). Will my child receive these services during the closure?
Services will not be provided during the closure, consistent with how this is handled on snow days.
Will my child’s special education liaison, related service provider, and Director of Special Education be available if I have a question during this two week closure?
The Assistant Superintendent for Student Services will be available to assist with specific questions as needed. Email:
What should I expect in regards to special education timelines, including requests for an Initial Evaluation on or after March 16th. What should I expect?

Any timelines associated with an initial evaluation request received on March 16th or during the three week closure, will be processed using day one of the timeline as the date the district re-opens. For example, if the district re-opens on April 7th, that would count as day one associated with the timeline for an initial evaluation request.
I am looking for general tips on how to support my child during this two week closure.
The District will be sending out
general tips on how to support your student during the school closure.
Are there any athletic, club, or activity events happening during this period of closure?
No. All school-related events are canceled during this period.
delay the start of the 2020 spring season to
What about “informal” or “captains’ practices” for sports teams?
Students need to observe social distancing during the period of school closure. Informal practices of any kind would be against the spirit of social distancing.
As of now, the Senior Prom is postponed indefinitely. We hope to be able to reschedule the Senior Prom for later in the spring.
) The Junior Prom has been cancelled. There are no plans to reschedule at this time.
For the time being, Graduation activities are still scheduled as planned. However, this is a very fluid situation and may have to change.
Senior Internships will be cancelled for this year. Seniors will need to return to school and attend their second semester classes once school re-opens.
Should everyone be practicing social distancing?

Now, we ask that you do your part. Creating social gatherings during the school outage will minimize the impact of closing school. Carefully consider the necessity of being together. This is not a vacation. It is an extreme measure to allow for social distancing so the virus is not spread. Not being exposed to the virus is the best way not to get sick. Please refer to this CDC webpage for other recommendations to prevent illness:
Will I be notified if I come into contact with someone who is a confirmed case?

): Local Boards of Health receive notification from the state department of confirmed cases in their respective towns. The local (or contracted) public health nurses are responsible for investigating and notifying all close contacts.
What is the District's role in this process?

): Because of HIPPA Laws around individual privacy, the Board of Health will not share any specifics regarding confirmed cases with the School District. The District will provide support to the local board of health nurses as requested.
How do I contact the local Boards of Health?
Where can I find resources to talk with my child about COVID-19?
): Here are some recommended resources for talking with your child:

: “Talking to Teens and Tweens about Coronavirus
: “Five Ways to Help Teens Manage Anxiety about the Coronavirus
Psychology Today “How to Talk to Kids and Teens about the Coronavirus.”
NPR: “Coronavirus and Parenting: What You Need to Know Now.”
